thread.title: Toowoomba farmers jet off to Shanghai to open doors
thread.title_full: Toowoomba farmers jet off to Shanghai to open doors

author: Pip Courtney
title: Toowoomba farmers jet off to Shanghai to open doors
text:
Map: China 
The opportunities for Australian farmers in China have been talked up for so long it is probably fair many have started asking "are we there yet?" 
The first step towards turning promise into profits was when the China-Australia Free Trade Agreement (ChAFTA) was signed in December 2015. 
The Federal Government says it is now up to Australian farmers to make the most of the deal, which will see the gradual elimination of a host of import tariffs ranging from 12 to 25 per cent by 2024. 
With this in mind, a delegation of 240 farmers and food manufacturers from the Toowoomba region in Queensland made history late last year when they flew to China to learn how to do business with Australia's biggest trading partner. 
The group flew out of the new Wellcamp international airport in Toowoomba, in South-East Queensland, with the trip organised by the Toowoomba and Surat Basin Enterprise (TSBE). 
"Transform that opportunity into new business," Assistant Minister for Trade, Tourism and Investment Keith Pitt told the delegation. 
"The ability of regions like yours to bring high value crops directly out of the Wellcamp airport provides a world of opportunity which you absolutely must grab with both hands." 
The TSBE is determined its farmers and food manufacturers capitalise on ChAFTA. 
"You'll never get anything done unless you go and see it yourself," said TSBE's CEO Ben Lyons. 
"You've got to go and shake the hand of a Chinese person and work out what they're after, it all works on a personal basis there, so it's really important." New airport built with China in mind 
The group was the first international passenger flight out of the new $200 million Wellcamp airport. 
On board was the president of Queensland lobby group AgForce, Grant Maudsley, who considered the trip very monumental. 
"If you had told me 10 years ago we'd be flying out of Toowoomba on an international flight going to China, not in your wildest dreams," he said. 
"A lot of vision's been shown to get this up and running now it's up to the producers and exporters to step up build those relationships and make it work." 
But when the local Wagner family built the new airport, they actually had China in mind. 
John Wagner said if it can become an Asian freight hub exporting the region's produce, it could transform the farming fortunes of not just locals but producers throughout Queensland. Aussie produce a hit on e-commerce giant Alibaba Photo: During the shopping frenzy known as Singles Day last year Alibaba did a staggering US$17.79 billion in sales in 24 hours. (ABC News) 
The delegation visited beef importers, freight handlers, ports and e-commerce operations including online juggernaut Alibaba. 
Alibaba has cornered 75 per cent of China's e-commerce trade, and 1,300 Australian businesses already use it to sell beef, fresh milk, honey, nuts, infant formula and vitamins. 
"It was mind-boggling, the figures on that screen were just mind-boggling," said Queensland orchardist Rosie Savio after the Alibaba tour. 
"I didn't realise that there was such an e-commerce business anywhere in the world." 
Demand for Australian produce was clear at online food e-tailer G-shop which imports Australian oysters, wagyu beef and fresh milk. 
In one day G-shop sold 16 tonnes of Australian single serve steaks through Alibaba. 
Austrade's Henry Wang told delegates they needed to understand the extraordinary rise of online, or e-commerce in China. 
"This is really a game changer, in the last year 413 million online consumers spent more than $750 billion online alone," he said. 
In the click and share country, where phones are in hand all the time, social media drives buying decisions. 
"In the future all commerce will be social," China-based PR consultant Darren Burns told delegates. 
In fact Queensland nut producer Stahmann Farms has been exporting to China for 18 months and found because many Chinese consumers do not buy food from a physical bricks and mortar shop, they needed to develop an online site and hire a social media staffer to upload content to China's equivalent of Facebook and Twitter — WeChat and Weibo. 
"Social media consumption in China is incredible, they don't buy anything unless they have done some form of research and that research is two and three second bites back into their own social media network or a network they trust," said sales manager Andrew Waddell. Photo: Inside the G-Shop store — Australian beef is its core product. (ABC News) Fruit and vegetables still still locked out 
However, despite the ChAFTA breakthrough several farmers on the trip were frustrated as their produce cannot be exported to China. 
Queensland vegetable grower Richard Gorman said the Federal Government was not doing enough to get more fruits and vegetables ticked off. 
"Cherries, citrus, beef, fresh milk they're all in there but for us in the world of vegetables we can't actually send anything fresh there at the moment, so we need our political leaders to ask for it," he said. 
"The trade deal's there and they've done a great job, now it's about making sure we've got the protocols that allow us to actually trade. 
"There's 200 Australians standing behind me that all paid their own way to be here, and the people of the political landscape at home need to see that, it's going to come down to our political leaders they're going to make this opportunity happen or not." More Window on China stories:
